posts.name: Alex Kempen
posts.cooked:
Hello all, I’m extremely happy to be finally sharing my latest and greatest FeatureScript projects. Most of these have been in development for quite some time now, so I’m excited to be finally sharing them with the community.

Variable Suite https://cad.onshape.com/documents/d33530b06909083111cf1770/w/5be0429e68b3332e158a3559/e/e4e782e0fe48a9227b9440aa Variable Library The variable library feature makes it possible to quickly import variables from one part studio to another. This makes it easier than ever to set and use global variables without having to mess around with feature studios or code. It can be used to build large libraries of variables which can be used by your entire team, or to quickly define a few variables which can then be parametrically used across several part studios in a project. Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/b1/03yyzrzh35pc.gif 860×404

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/b1/03yyzrzh35pc.gif 860×404

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/b1/03yyzrzh35pc.gif 860×404

Variable Hole The variable hole feature utilizes variables to transfer entire hole definitions. This makes it possible to create variables which can then be used to instantly define an entire hole, including information like counterbore/countersink, standard, hole type, tap size/depth, and so on. And thanks to my variable library feature, it’s easy to setup and use these variables across your entire team. Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/al/8nrriiuopj9r.png 857×416

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/al/8nrriiuopj9r.png 857×416

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/al/8nrriiuopj9r.png 857×416

Variable Properties Variable Properties behaves similarly to the Variable Hole feature, making it possible to create variables which can be used to quickly define part color and material type. Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/11/pobir24cjyza.png 1102×580

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/11/pobir24cjyza.png 1102×580

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/11/pobir24cjyza.png 1102×580

Plate Suite https://cad.onshape.com/documents/2c2b49357f3f1a232881256a/w/6258e1943ecedc8606542dd7/e/78e9b9148efe7163309beca0 Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/tx/4zwa4trny4xp.png 939×754 ﻿﻿Plate Extrude The plate extrude feature allows users to quickly extrude flat geometry. The plate extrude feature can be used as a standalone feature, or it can be used in conjunction with other plate features. Useful options include the ability to select a plate plane to extrude off of, symmetric up to behavior, and the ability to extrude adjacent faces as separate parts. Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/xi/qruvfmgrybzh.png 1179×700

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/tx/4zwa4trny4xp.png 939×754

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/tx/4zwa4trny4xp.png 939×754

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/xi/qruvfmgrybzh.png 1179×700

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/xi/qruvfmgrybzh.png 1179×700

Plate Tab The plate tab feature serves as an alternative to the plate extrude feature which creates plates centered around single holes. This can be used to create tabs which connect to existing geometry, or to quickly create simple linkages from scratch. Useful options include the ability to use variables from the variable hole feature, and the ability to define start and end conditions for tabs. Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/fw/cay56mdmiedp.png 586×573 Plate Hole The plate hole feature can be used to quickly add holes to plates created by a plate extrude or plate tab feature. Holes can be defined manually or by using a hole variable created by a variable hole feature. Useful options include being able to arbitrarily flip the side of the plate holes originate from, and the ability to define new holes as tabs, adding them alongside new geometry to existing plates. Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/7a/58tuj3nyi62f.png 905×560 Plate Fillet The plate fillet feature makes it easy to quickly fillet plates. Useful options include the ability to fillet an entire plate at once, the ability to select faces and edges to exclude, and the ability to add full round fillets to the sides of plates with a single click. Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/aj/r9c2f152db10.png 691×711 Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/nm/59hntqq357xh.png 976×409

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/fw/cay56mdmiedp.png 586×573

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/fw/cay56mdmiedp.png 586×573

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/7a/58tuj3nyi62f.png 905×560

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/7a/58tuj3nyi62f.png 905×560

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/aj/r9c2f152db10.png 691×711

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/aj/r9c2f152db10.png 691×711

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/nm/59hntqq357xh.png 976×409

Image: https://us.v-cdn.net/5022071/uploads/editor/nm/59hntqq357xh.png 976×409

Oh, and for those curious, here are some quick stats: 21 different feature studios ~50 unique custom error messages ~3,800 lines of code ~way to much of my free time

Thanks for reading, and I hope you find them useful! Alex Kempen

posts.name: Michael Ray
posts.cooked:
6800 has started to go down the variable suite featurescript route this summer, and plan to try it out this upcoming build season.

A few suggestions from different things I found out when creating our featurescripts:

Feedback I got from @MCarroll94 when he went to use our variable suite was that it was easier if the variables were separated out.

Specifically, imagine putting a tolerance into your variable archive. Now that tolerance could differ depending on what machine you are using to manufacture your part. Instead of having different names for each tolerance for each machine, you could use #tolerance but have it import from your 3D Printer variable suite instead of your Router variable suite.

Our solution was to have a variety of variable suites and you add your variable suite to your feature list depending on the machines you need to use:

For a part studio that has lots of machinery used, you just add all of the variable suites:

Another piece of feedback I received and then implemented was that it was hard to view what variables were available to you when designing a part.

Therefore we implemented a custom table that goes along with each variable suite. That way when you hit the custom table button on the right side of your onshape workspace panel, it shows the available tables (that are associated with each variable suite) and what variables are available.

See an example of one of the tables below.

image 722×382 25.3 KB

image 722×382 25.3 KB

image 722×382 25.3 KB

Note that I added a description, value, and units column so that you knew the details of each variable. I want to make the units convert automatically based on the document unit properties in the future, but thats a discussion for another time
